data.title: Commencement program, USC (77th: 1960: Alumni Memorial Park)
data.text:
Content UNIVERSITY OF SouTHERN CALIFORNIA

SEVENTY-SEVENTH

ANNUAL

COMMENCEMENT

THURSDAY, JUNE 9, 1960

ALUMNI MEMORIAL PARK

ALMA MATER

All hail to Alma Mater,

To thy glory we sing;

All hail to Southern California,

Loud let our praises ring;

Where western sky meets western sea

Our college stands in majesty.

Sing our love to Alma Mater,

Hail, all hail, to thee.

Diplomas and certificates will be awarded by deans of the various schools in

separate ceremonies immediately following the general commencement exercises,

For location of these ceremonies, please see the inside back cover.

HONORARY DEGREES

GWYNN WILSON-DOCTOR OF HUMANE LETTERS

Well known throughout Southern California for his contribution to

the dvic, cultural, and educational growth of the entire state, this

outstanding alumnus has given distinguished service to his univer­ sity over the past forty years. After serving in the United States

Navy during World War I, he was Graduate Manager of the Uni­ versity for ten years and has been a member of the Faculty Ath­ letic Committee, President of the General Alumni Association, a

Trustee, and since 1954 Secretary of the Board of Trustees. Al­ though born in Portland, Oregon, he received his education in the

Santa Monica and Pomona, California, public school systems and

earned a Bachelor of Arts degree at the University of Southern

California in 1921. When the outstanding business, civic, and cul­ tural leaders of California organized the Community Development

Association and subsequently The Xth Olympiad Committee of the

1932 Games in Los Angeles, they searched the entire United States

for a man capable of direct managerial ability and selected the

Graduate Manager of the University of Southern California as

their associate manager. He achieved wide recognition for his effi­

cient work, which was largely responsible for the excellence of the

1932 Olympic Games. He was also the Assistant Managing Direc­ tor of the Golden Gate International Exposition in 1939. He has

given both personal and financial assistance to most worth-while

community efforts and lent his executive services to such organiza­

tions as the Hollywood Bowl Association, State of California Mount

San Jacinto Winter Park Authority, Los Angeles Chamber of Com­ merce, Olympic Games Committee of Southern California, Welfare

Federation of Los Angeles Board of Governors, and All Year Club

of Southern California. He is widely recognized for his multitudi­

nous contributions and achievements in an almost unbelievable

spread of community interests, outstanding personal success in the

businec.,s world, and dedicated devotion and service to the Univer­

sity of Southern California.

Presented by HAROLD C. MoRTON, Member - of the Board of Trustees

[ 3 ]

4 HONORARY DEGREES

JAMES ALBERT P1KE-DocTOR OF LAws

Jurist, orator, teacher, and clergyman, this man by his return to

California to be consecrated as a Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal

Ch1,:irch and, in 1958, to become the Bishop of California has hap­ pily been brought nearer to the University of Southern California,

which has been proud to have him as a distinguished alumnus

during the twenty-four years of his notable and varied life career

since his graduation in 1936 from its School of Law. A native.of

Oklahoma, he attended three California universities in preparation

for the legal profession and then earned his doctorate in juridical

science at Yale University. The promise of outstanding achiev_ e­

ments in the law, evidenced by his work until the end of World

War II for the Securities and Exchange . Commission and . the

United States Navy, gave way to his vocation·to the Christian min­

istry. He was ordained to the priesthood of the Episcopal Church

in 1946, following study in Virginia and Union Theological semi­

naries, and served as rector of Christ Church in Poughkeepsie, New

York. Then Columbia University.called him to be its Chaplain. and

Head of the Department of Religion, and three years later, in 1952,

he became Dean of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine

in New York. The power and influence of his utterances from the

Cathedral's pulpit and over the radio, and the wide circulation of

the important and timely books which came from his busy pen,

brought him into such high respect and such general renown that

his election to fill one of his church's most-important offices seemed

only natural. Tirelessly and perceptively he continues to serve his

people, his trained mind alert to the problems and needs of state

and society and the church, his opinions and judgments always

unequivocally and forcefully stated, and his heart unquestioningly

dedicated to the religious vocation through which he serves his God

and his fellow men.

Presented by H. LESLIE HoFFMAN, Member of the Board of Trustees

ALBERT s. R.AuBENHEIMER......:_DocTOR OF SCIENCE

This distinguished educator was born in South Africa, where he

received his undergraduate training at the University of the Cape

of Good Hope and earned a Master of Arts degree at the University

of Cape Town. After coming to America, he studied at Columbia

University and in 1923 received his Ph.D. degree in Educational

HONORARY DEGREES 5

Psychology from Stanford University under the guidance of Dr.

Lewis M. Terman. In the fall of that year he came to the Univer­

sity of Southern California as a member of the faculty of the School

of Education. For thirty-seven years he has served this university

as professor, Dean of the College of Letters, Arts, and Sciences,

Director of the Educational Program, and for the past fourteen

years as Educational Vice-President and Vice-President, Academic

Affairs. Throughout these years his work has been characterized

by steadfast devotion to duty, sterling integrity, and firm but con­

siderate administration of the many academic programs of the

University. Twice he has been a member of an interim adminis­

trative committee when the University was without a president.

He has served as President of the Western College Association and

as guest lecturer and teacher in several other colleges and univer­

sities. His abiding interest in the mental well-being of children led

to his appointment as Chairman of the Governor's Committee on

Mental Health in 1949. He later served as Chairman of the Gov­

ernor's Committee on Penal Institutions. His contributions to his

community and state have gone far beyond the University and

have contributed greatly to the progress of the state of which he

is a valiant citizen.

Presented by FRANK L. KING, Member of the Board of Trustees

EDWARD TELLER-DOCTOR OF SCIENCE

Born in Hungary and educated in Germany, this distinguished

scientist has made his outstanding contributions to chemical and

nuclear physics in America. As a member of an elite group of

farsighted physicists who first communicated to President Roose­

velt the potentiality of uranium as a new source of energy, he

was an early proponent of the atomic bomb. During a subsequent

decade from 1941 to 1951-at the Manhattan District, the Metal­

lurgical Laboratory in Chicago, and Los Alamos-his brilliant in­

sight and investigations led to the practical realization of the ther­

monuclear reaction, and he became one of the principal architects

of the H-bomb. His studies in radiation, nuclear energy, and the

fundamental particles of matter have continued at the University

of California Radiation Laboratory in Livermore, of which he was

Director from 1958 until this year. In yet another branch of sci­

entific inquiry, his method of surface-area measurement is funda­

mental to the study of colloids and catalysts. In recognition of his

accomplishments, he was named by President Eisenhower to mem-

6 HONORARY DEGREES

bership on the General Advisory Committee to the Atomic Energy

Commission in 1956, was the recipient of the Joseph Priestly Me­

morial Award in 1957, and was awarded the Albert Einstein medal

in 1958. He is today a strong advocate of science education and

basic research in America. Not content with his masterly perform­

ance as teacher of physics in several of the world's great univer­

sities, he has been a tireless worker for public realization and un­

derstanding of the implications of atomic physics and nuclear

energy, in preparation for the nuclear age.

Presented by NORMAN CHANDLER, Member of the Board of Trustees

J.E. WALLACE STERLING--DOCTOR OF LETTERS

J. E. Wallace Sterling: historian, educator, academic administra­

tor, and a Canadian by birth. He received his early education in

Canada and earned his Bachelor of Arts degree at the University

of Toronto in 1927 and Master of Arts degree at the University

of Alberta in 1930. He entered Stanford University to further

pursue his interest in the humanities and in 1938 was awarded

his Ph.D. in History. From 1937 to 1948 he was a member of the

faculty of the California Institute of Technology, where his in­

terest and abilities in transmitting his knowledge of history to

others were rewarded by a professorship. In 1948 he accepted the

invitation by the Huntington Library and Art Gallery to become

its director and served this famous institution admirably. He was

called back to his alma mater in 1949 as Fifth President of Stan­

ford University. Through these twelve years he has done much

to enhance the reputation of that university, regarded highly both

here and abroad. He has been an adviser at every level on educa­

tional matters, clearly presenting the case for better education for

our youth. Stanford, with his guidance, now stands not only as a

shining example but as an encouragement for all the independent

colleges and universities in California.

Presented by AsA V. CALL, President of the Board of Trustees
